natural solution: We can rewrite the summand as \[\begin{aligned} \log_2\left(1+\frac1k\right) \log_k2 \log_{k+1}2 &= \frac{ \log_2\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log_2 k \log_2 (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log_2(k+1) - \log_2 k}{\log_2 k \log_2 (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{1}{\log_2 k} - \frac{1}{\log_2 (k+1)}.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes k :: real and f g h :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 2 \<and> k \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> f k = log 2 (1 + 1/k)"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 2 \<and> k \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> g k = log k 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 2 \<and> k \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> h k = log (k+1) 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 2 \<and> k \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> f k * g k * h k = 1"
shows  "(\<Sum> k \<leftarrow> [2..63]. f k * g k * h k) = 5/6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute \[\sum_{k=2}^{63} \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2.\] The final Answer is \frac56
 ### Proof
 We can rewrite the summand as \[\begin{aligned} \log_2\left(1+\frac1k\right) \log_k2 \log_{k+1}2 &= \frac{ \log_2\left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)}{\log_2 k \log_2 (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{\log_2(k+1) - \log_2 k}{\log_2 k \log_2 (k+1)} \\ &= \frac{1}{\log_2 k} - \frac{1}{\log_2 (k+1)}.
 \end{aligned}\]Therefore, the sum telescopes: \[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=2}^{63} \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2 &= \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 2} - \frac{1}{\log_2 3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 3} - \frac1{\log_2 4}\right) + \dots + \left(\frac{1}{\log_2 63} - \frac{1}{\log_2 64}\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{\log_2 2} - \frac{1}{\log_2 64} \\ &= 1 - \frac16 \\ &= \boxed{\frac56}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes k :: real and f g h :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 2 \<and> k \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> f k = log 2 (1 + 1/k)"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 2 \<and> k \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> g k = log k 2"

If the product of $f(k)$, $g(k)$, and $h(k)$ is always 1 for these values of $k$, then what is the sum of the products $f(k) * g(k) * h(k)$ for all $k$ from 2 to 63? The final answer is $\frac{5}{6}$.

 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

(* ### Problem
 Compute \[\sum_{k=2}^{63} \log_2\left(1 + \frac{1}{k}\right) \log_k 2 \log_{k+1} 2.\] The final Answer is \frac56

 *)

 *)

 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

and h2 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 2 \<and> k \<le> 63 \<longrightarrow> log 2 (1 + 1 / real k) * log k 2 * log (k+1) 2 = f k"
shows  "sum f 63 = 5 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: For a logarithm function defined as $log(base, num) = \frac{ln(num)}{ln(base)}$ and a sum function defined as the sum of an arithmetic series $f(k)$ from $2$ to $n$, if $\forall k (2 \leq k \leq 63)$ the function $f(k)$ is defined as $log(2, 1 + 1 / k) * log(k, 2) * log(k+1, 2)$, find the value of the sum of this series up to $63$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{6}$.
